awd_titl_txt: CCRI: Planning: Infrastructure for Collaborative Autonomy Testing
awd_abstract_narration:
Teams of autonomous ground robots and unmanned vehicles will be used in missions such as search-and-rescue, mining, material handling, and protecting secure facilities.  Computer scientists and engineers are inventing and enhancing new algorithms that these autonomous systems will use to collaborate with each other.  Better algorithms will improve team performance.  Currently, testing such algorithms requires extensive time and resources to setup and run simulation models and other facilities that are needed for test and evaluation, validation and verification.  This project will lay the foundation for a modeling and simulation infrastructure that will reduce barriers to research and development of autonomous systems and will enable collaboration in this important research area.  This will accelerate the implementation of these systems that will have numerous benefits to society.

This project will plan a community research infrastructure.  The planning process will include a broad-based community of researchers from multiple institutions, including experts in robotics systems, modeling and simulation, test & evaluation, and software engineering, and will engage them in multiple ways. The planning group will develop use cases, design the infrastructure architecture, and identify key partners. A broader group will provide input via a survey and a workshop at a robotics conference. The ultimate deliverable of this planning project will be a proposal to be submitted in January 2022.  The infrastructure will include hardware, software, APIs, user interfaces, libraries of models, a development and testing environment, and documentation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project laid the foundation for a new proposal to the NSF Community Infrastructure for Research in Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE) program.  The proposed project will create the Infrastructure for Collaborative Autonomy Testing (ICAT), which will support CISE research on cooperative multi-robot systems (MRS). In particular, the ICAT will be a collection of software and hardware resources for developing, simulating, and testing MRS applications in a wide variety of domains. Support for air, ground, and underwater domains will distinguish ICAT from existing hardware and software platforms that are focused on specific domains.

As part of our CCRI planning process, we conducted an information gathering survey in early 2022 to collect information from members of the CISE community to understand the needs of the MRS research community.  Better simulation tools, simulation models, and access to testing facilities were the needs that respondents mentioned most often.  

We then organized a workshop at the RSS 2022 conference at Columbia University on July 1, 2022.  The workshop title was Envisioning an Infrastructure for Multi-Robot and Collaborative Autonomy Testing and Evaluation.  The workshop included keynote sessions with five invited talks (Table 1 lists the topics of those talks), a contributed talks session with five talks, and a panel discussion with the invited speakers and workshop participants.  The workshop was held in person but also had online participants.

The following organizations are proposing to develop ICAT: the University of Maryland, Johns Hopkins University, the Catholic University of America, and Fraunhofer USA.

ICAT, a new community research, infrastructure, will accelerate research in key MRS areas by reducing the time and effort required to build and test MRS applications. These areas include multi-domain operations, navigation algorithms for computing safe paths through complex terrain, long-distance collaborative autonomy, and mission planning algorithms for operations in megacities. The proposed infrastructure will enable researchers and system developers to build and run different types of simulation models quickly to evaluate, test, and improve their algorithms and systems. They will then easily move from simulations to physical devices for field experiments and quickly proceed to analyzing those results.

This infrastructure will reduce the time, cost, and effort required to create the applications and simulation testbeds needed for MRS research. This will lower the barriers to conducting such research, which will expand access and allow research groups that lack such resources to participate in the research community. Increasing access will lower barriers to research collaborations in the MRS domain and will expand the CISE MRS research community.


Last Modified: 08/11/2023
Modified by: Jeffrey W Herrmann
